p.seg: STATE OF NEBRASKA Biennial Report OF THE Superintendent OF THE State Industrial School KEARNEY, NEBRASKA To the Governor and the Board of Control of State Institutions For the Period Ending June 30, 1923

FOREWORD To His Excellency, the Governor : The Board of Control herewith transmits the Fifth Biennial Report of the State Institutions of Nebraska for the period ending June 30, 1923. The biennium formerly ended on November 30 of each even-numbered year, but this date was changed by an act of the legislature, so that this report really covers a period of thirty-one months from December 1, 1920, to June 30, 1923. During the period, no change has occurred in the personnel of the Board, but several changes have been made in the chief officers of institutions. Dr. Beverly A. Finkle, superintendent of the Orthopedic Hospital, Lincoln, Nebraska, resigned to enter private practice, and was succeeded on August 23, 1921, by Dr. J. H. Matthai. Miss Amy V. Stevens, who had been superintendent of the Home for Dependent Children, Lincoln, Nebraska, for a number of years, resigned on July 5, 1922, being succeeded by her sister, Miss Nellie Stevens. The latter served until February 19, 1923, when her resignation was received, and Miss Lena Driever was appointed to the position. We call attention with pride and pleasure to the fact that the report shows the institutions to have gone through the bien - nium without incurring any deficiencies ; although the cost of living, and consequently the cost of supporting the state's depen - dents, has certainly not decreased since the appropriations were made for the biennium. Some improvements of a permament character have been made at the various institutions during the period covered by this report. A hospital building, bakery and scullery have been erected at the Nebraska Institution for Feeble Minded, Beatrice, Nebraska ; a cottage for girls at the Girls' Training School, Geneva, Nebraska ; a hospital building at the Soldiers and Sailors' Home, Burkett,

4 Nebraska; a gymnasium building at the State Industrial School, Kearney, Nebraska; a hospital building at the Hospital for Tuberculous, Kearney, Nebraska; a farm house and a barn at the Lincoln State Hospital, Lincoln, Nebraska ; a warehouse at the State Penitentiary, Lincoln, Nebraska ; a hospital building at the Soldiers and Sailors' Home, Milford, Nebraska ; a kitchen building at the Norfolk State Hospital, Norfolk, Nebraska ; a main building at the State Reformatory for Women, York, Nebraska. These buildings were badly needed, and they will have to be followed by others in the very near future if our wards are to be properly, efficiently and economically cared for. The legislature just past made provision for two or three buildings, but failed to see the necessity for several others that were urgently requested. Brief mention was made in the last report of the establishment of the Reformatory for Men at Lincoln, but the importance of the institution calls, we believe, for rather more extended notice. This institution was established as a result, primarily, of a wide recognition of the need of segregating young first-term offenders from more mature criminals. The legislature of 1921 authorized the establishment, therefore, of such an institution, making an initial approproation of $300,000. Of this sum the Board ex - pended $37,500 for 10 acres and a brick building known as the Hayward Military Academy, later buying about 152 acres of contiguous land for the sum of $49,531.25. This land is used for farming, stock raising, dairying, and intensive gardening. Various trades are taught such as tailoring, shoe repairing, carpentry and joinery, brick laying, electricity, automobile repairing, launder - ing, engineering, firing, and barbering. The manual labor about the institution is, of course, performed by the inmates, of which there are at this date 189. Mr. A. W. Miller, the superintendent, is doing much constructive work with the young men committed to his charge, and we believe the institution is amply justifying itself. The difficulty of employing the penitentiary inmates at suitable labor that does not conflict too much with the prerogatives of the free workers of our state, has been pretty well overcome. The state still operates the fibre furniture factory which has been at the prison for some years, and has also established relations with the Oberman Company by which shirts are made and disposed of with a minimum of competition with free labor.

7 Home for Dependent Children, Lincoln — Grand Total. 4,538,783.65 At its various institutions the state owns something over 4000 acres of land, of which in excess of 3500 are in farm and garden. About 800 acres are rented in addition. Details of operation are given in the reports from the several superintendents which are appended hereto. The health of the inmate population has been generally good during the past biennium. We are pleased to be able to report that no epidemic has broken out at any of the institutions, and our medical men have been able to cope with such sporadic cases of contagious disease as have appeared. In conclusion we wish to express our appreciation of the efforts of the officers and employees of the various institutions in striving to bring about a betterment of the living conditions of the wards under their care. We wish also to thank the Governor for his manifestations of interest and for his assistance in the work of this department, and we trust that he will continue his efforts to help us provide better means of caring for the wards of the state. 17 STATE INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL Kearney, Nebraska OFFICERS R. V. CLARK F. R. DICKSON S. W. BISSELL J. L. BENNETT Superintendent Assistant Superintendent Steward Physician MRS. MINNIE ALBRIGHT Matron MisceLaneous Statement Boys' and Girls' Industrial School 1879-1891 Established as State Industrial School for Boys 1891 Number of employees 40 Number of inmates June 30, 1923 207 Highest number of inmates 241 Per capita cost per month $ 3528 Number of acres 602 Number of acres rented 60 Number of acres under cultivation 602 Value of lands and buildings $ 423,496.34 Principal Industries — Farming, stock-raising. Particular attention is given to manual training. Visiting Days — Afternoons from 2 to 5, excepting Saturday and Sunday. Admission to the school is through commitment by court and is confined to sane boys under 18 found guilty of crime (except homicide) or boys under 16 who are beyond parental control. Boys are required to remain until 21 years of age, unless sooner released by court order or paroled by the Superintendent.

19 To the Governor and the Board of Control of State Institutions, Lincoln, Nebraska : I respectfully present the Superintendent's Report of the State Industrial School for Boys for the period ending June 30, 1923. Our school opened this year with an enrollment of 212 and closed with 218 boys. The school work included the grades from one to ten inclusive. Four rooms are devoted to the teaching of school subjects, one room to the teaching of music and fourteen rooms to the teaching of trades, or manual training. The manual training and trade departments are as follows : Baking, cooking, carpentry, laundering, mechanics, painting, print - ing, shoemakng and tailoring. Each boy attends the graded school one-half of each day, and works in the trades school the other half. Under supervision the boys learn the practical art of baking. This department contributes annually 53,000 loaves of bread, besides cakes, etc. A demand constantly exists for experienced bakers. Our boys learn a practical trade which will later demand for them a living wage. For our colored boys, especially, many of whom will follow this line of work as men, culinary details furnish good training. The carpenter shop is a place of industry. The cutting, fram - ing and joining of timber is taught ; farm implements, furniture, etc., are repaired, windows are replaced about the institution. The wood work for the forms of the new tunnels were built by this de - partment. The laundry is well equipped. Washing, cleaning, dyeing, ironing, pressing, marking, counting, sorting and delivering are here taught, and the clothing of 250 people is laundered. The workers of the laundry are paroled with a trade which will bring a living. There is a world-wide demand for real mechanics. The machine shop and boiler room offer training to our boys. Three large boilers are fired and accompanying machinery kept in repair. An efficient engineer directs the work in this dpartment.

20 We are proud of our painting detail. Upon these boys and their capable instructor depends the neat appearance of the school both externally and internally. Mixing paint and skillfully apply - ing same is a good trade for the boys. These boys are furnished practical work which gives them experience. The school printing office furnishes some of the printed forms used by the seventeen institutions. It does all the printing for this school and also publishes a monthly paper. The boys in the print - ing office become proficient in a desirable and profitable trade, and are holding paying positions throughout the state. The office is equipped with two good job presses and one modern cylinder press. One new up-to-date Intertype machine has been added to the equipment. About $1700 has been earned for the state by our printers in the last twelve months. The department of shoemaking is also of commercial value to the institution. The boys of this detail save much which would otherwise be spent to purchase shoes. Our handmade shoes are of better leather, stronger material, and are more thoroughly sewed. Some of the boys learn the trade so thoroughly that one can make a pair of good shoes in a working day. For our 200 boys not one shoe is purchased on the market. Each boy of this school has two pairs of shoes, one pair for work, a second pair for Sunday. Har - ness and other leather repairs are attended to by the shoemakers. The tailoring department makes the clothing for the boys of the school. Excepting caps, stockings and collars, all articles of clothing are made by the tailors. They work of course under the direction of an expert cutter and tailor. Music is furnished by a twenty-one piece band under the direc - tion of an able instructor. The band is a source of entertainment to the boys of the school, and to the citizens of Kearney and neighboring communities. For its services in the last biennium the band has brought the state $684.65. The school has twenty-two horses and mules. The boys of the barn detail pride themselves upon the care of these animals. The man in charge, as well as the boys and teams, are busy almost daily with the institution hauling and farm work. The dairy comprises 62 tuberculin-tested Holstein cows. The entire herd consists of one hundred and thirty-five. It is valued at $14,000. The boys of the dairy detail gain valuable experience

21 in the feeding and care of cows. Milk and cream have been sold netting the state $9125.53 during the period ending June 30, 1923. The boys of the school generally have been healthy and strong. The marked improvement in the physical condition of many boys after entering has been noted with satisfaction. The Merit System The merit system is a marked aid in maintaining discipline throughout the school. Each boy is required to earn 1S,OOO credits before he is entitled to parole. The better his behavior, and the more diligent in work and study, the more rapidly he gains his credits. Each boy determines to the greatest possible degree the length of his stay in the school. Some boys have earned their paroles in nine months, others in fourteen months and a few have remained seventeen months. The boy who receives no demerits for twdve months is rewarded by the gift of one month off his term ; truthfulness for twelve months gains two months' credit. This syste n serves the dual purpose of securing good deportment and minimizing the necessity for corporal punishment. The employees have been mindful of the moral training due the boys of this school, and constant endeavor is made to encourage them to lead pure lives. Their spiritual welfare is nourished, we hope, by means of the chapel exercises each Sunday afternoon at three o'clock, and by the Sunday School lessons taught in their companies. Ministers are invited to speak who will encourage the boys to live Christian lives. Our farm of 620 acres provides more work for our boys than any other department. Certainly the boys who work on the farm will be forcefully impressed with the resourcefulness of rural life and its advantages. Two notable improvements were made in our institution in 1922-23 : A new brick gymnasium 55 feet wide by 109 feet long furnishes ample opportunities for athletic sports such as basket ball, wrestling and boxing; also permitting an ideal arrangement for the giving of the weekly picture show and other entertan - ments. On Sunday the auditorium furnishes facilities for the chapel exercises. The second marked improvement is the tunnel system com - pletely installed by our own boys and men. One hundred three rods of tunnels extend all around the campus rectangle and enter

22 each cottage, the main building, the trades building and the new gymnasium. These tunnels, which are six feet three inches high in the clear and six feet wide, furnish ideal channels through which run the new heat pipe lines, and also the new hot and cold water lines. More than that ; the boys can march during storms and darkness comfortably and safely. The boys having done the work, the State expended money for material only at a total expense of $6000.00. These tunnels are the most beneficial material improve - ment to the State Industrial School made in the last two decades. Our sincere thanks are hereby given to faithful co-workers who have assisted and encouraged the Superintendent in this important work with delinquent boys. R. V. CLARK, Superintendent
